# List of Washington Capitals seasons

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![See
caption](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Washington_Capitals_retired_numbers_red.jpg/300px-
Washington_Capitals_retired_numbers_red.jpg)](/wiki/File:Washington_Capitals_retired_numbers_red.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Washington_Capitals_retired_numbers_red.jpg "Enlarge")

Banners at the [Capital One Arena](/wiki/Capital_One_Arena "Capital One
Arena") showing the Capitals' [retired numbers](/wiki/Retired_number "Retired
number")

The [Washington Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") are
a professional [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") team based in
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") The team is a
member of the [Metropolitan Division](/wiki/Metropolitan_Division_\(NHL\)
"Metropolitan Division \(NHL\)") of the [Eastern
Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NHL\) "Eastern Conference \(NHL\)") of
the [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey
League") (NHL). The Capitals played at the [Capital
Centre](/wiki/Capital_Centre "Capital Centre") from their inaugural season in
1974 to 1997, when they moved to the MCI Center, now known as the [Capital One
Arena](/wiki/Capital_One_Arena "Capital One Arena"). In 42 completed seasons,
the Capitals have qualified for the [Stanley Cup
playoffs](/wiki/Season_structure_of_the_NHL#Stanley_Cup_playoffs "Season
structure of the NHL") 27 times, making two [Stanley Cup
Finals](/wiki/Stanley_Cup_Finals "Stanley Cup Finals") appearances during the
[1997–98](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_Washington_Capitals_season "1997–98 Washington
Capitals season") and [2017–18
seasons](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Washington_Capitals_season "2017–18 Washington
Capitals season"), winning [the latter](/wiki/2018_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2018
Stanley Cup Finals").

The Capitals were founded in 1974 as an expansion team in the [Prince of Wales
Conference](/wiki/Prince_of_Wales_Conference "Prince of Wales Conference").
The team had an 8–67–5 record and lost 37 straight road games in their
[inaugural season](/wiki/1974%E2%80%9375_Washington_Capitals_season "1974–75
Washington Capitals season").[1] The Capitals made their first playoffs in the
[1982–83 season](/wiki/1982%E2%80%9383_Washington_Capitals_season "1982–83
Washington Capitals season") and qualified for the playoffs for the following
13 seasons in a row. The Capitals won the Eastern Conference during their
[1997–98 season](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_Washington_Capitals_season "1997–98
Washington Capitals season") but were swept by the [Detroit Red
Wings](/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings") in the [1998 Stanley Cup
Finals](/wiki/1998_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1998 Stanley Cup Finals").[2]

After reaching the Finals, the Capitals were assigned to the Southeast
Division, in which they remained in for 15 years, until a NHL division
realignment brought them into the newly formed Metropolitan Division in 2013.
Through these times, the Capitals won three [Presidents'
Trophies](/wiki/Presidents%27_Trophy "Presidents' Trophy") in the
[2009–10](/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_Washington_Capitals_season "2009–10 Washington
Capitals season"), [2015–16](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Washington_Capitals_season
"2015–16 Washington Capitals season") and [2016–17
seasons](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Washington_Capitals_season "2016–17 Washington
Capitals season"),[3] before finally winning their first ever [Stanley
Cup](/wiki/Stanley_Cup "Stanley Cup") in the [2017–18
season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Washington_Capitals_season "2017–18 Washington
Capitals season"), after 42 seasons (not counting the cancelled [2004–05
season](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_Washington_Capitals_season "2004–05 Washington
Capitals season")).

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Washington_Capitals_seasons&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Notes")]

  * **a** In 1992, the NHL expanded the season to 84 games, and each team played two games at a neutral site. After the 1995 lockout, the neutral site games were eliminated, and the season was reduced to 82 games.[34]
  * **b** The NHL realigned into Eastern and Western conferences prior to the 1993–94 season.[35] Washington was placed in the Atlantic Division of the Eastern Conference.[36]
  * **c** The season was shortened to 48 games because of the [1994–95 NHL lockout](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_NHL_lockout "1994–95 NHL lockout").[37]
  * **d** Beginning with the 1999–00 season, teams received one point for losing a regular season game in overtime.[38]
  * **e** The season was canceled because of the [2004–05 NHL lockout](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_NHL_lockout "2004–05 NHL lockout").[39]
  * **f** Before the 2005–06 season, the NHL instituted a [penalty shootout](/wiki/Overtime_\(ice_hockey\)#Shootout "Overtime \(ice hockey\)") for regular season games that remained tied after a five-minute overtime period, which prevented ties.[40]
  * **g** The NHL added 4 expansion teams prior to the 1998–99 season and split the Eastern Conference into three divisions: [Northeast](/wiki/Northeast_Division_\(NHL\) "Northeast Division \(NHL\)"), [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Division_\(NHL\) "Atlantic Division \(NHL\)"), and [Southeast](/wiki/Southeast_Division_\(NHL\) "Southeast Division \(NHL\)"). Washington was moved into the new Southeast division.[41]
  * **h** The season was shortened to 48 games because of the [2012–13 NHL lockout](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NHL_lockout "2012–13 NHL lockout").[42]
  * **i** The NHL realigned prior to the 2013–14 season. Washington was placed in the Metropolitan Division of the Eastern Conference.[43]
